security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and workflow guidance. All static analysis findings were false positives - the 'external commands' and 'cryptographic algorithms' were merely text descriptions in documentation, not executable code.

content.value_statement: Stop wasting time guessing how to approach tasks. This skill enforces a disciplined workflow that ensures you use the right tools and methods every time. It eliminates rationalization and establishes clear protocols for skill invocation.
actual_capabilities: Enforces mandatory skill checking before any response
Provides decision flowchart for skill invocation
Lists common rationalization patterns to avoid
Establishes priority order for multiple applicable skills
Defines rigid vs flexible skill types
limitations: Only provides guidance, doesn't execute tasks directly
Requires user to have skills available in their environment
Does not replace critical thinking about skill applicability
Protocol must be followed consistently to be effective

use_cases.title: Learn proper skill usage habits
use_cases.description: Build disciplined workflow habits from day one by following the mandatory skill checking protocol

use_cases.title: Optimize complex task workflows
use_cases.description: Apply systematic skill invocation to ensure no tool or method is overlooked in multi-step projects

use_cases.title: Standardize AI assistant usage
use_cases.description: Ensure consistent, thorough approach to tasks across team members using AI assistants

prompt_templates.title: Basic task check
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to [describe task]. What skills might apply to this? Check using the skill protocol.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-skill workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm starting a [type] project. Walk me through the skill priority order to ensure I use the right approach.

prompt_templates.title: Debug rationalization
prompt_templates.scenario: When tempted to skip skill checks
prompt_templates.prompt: I was about to skip checking skills because [reason]. Show me why this is rationalization and what to do instead.

prompt_templates.title: Skill type decision
prompt_templates.scenario: Choosing between rigid and flexible approaches
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I know if a skill is rigid (must follow exactly) or flexible (can adapt)? Give me examples.

output_examples.input: I need to fix a bug in my React app
output: Using debugging skill to establish systematic approach
Skill indicates: first reproduce issue, then isolate root cause
Check for React-specific skills after debugging protocol
Follow skill checklist: write failing test, verify fix, run full test suite

output_examples.input: Build a new API endpoint for user authentication
output: Multiple skills apply - following priority order
Process skill first: brainstorming for security requirements
Implementation skills: API design patterns, authentication methods
Rigid skills for: testing strategy, security validation

best_practices: Always invoke skills even for seemingly simple tasks - complexity often hides in details
Announce skill usage to maintain transparency in your workflow
Trust the skill over your assumptions - they contain evolved best practices
Complete skill checklists fully before moving to next steps
anti_patterns: Skipping skill checks because you 'know' the answer - skills evolve and contain nuances
Starting work before checking skills - this wastes time when better approaches exist
Partially following skills - rigid skills require exact adherence to maintain discipline
Assuming skills don't apply to clarifications - check before asking follow-up questions

faq.question: Why must I check skills before even asking clarifying questions?
faq.answer: Skills often contain specific methods for gathering information. Checking first ensures you use the most effective approach.

faq.question: What if I'm certain no skill applies to my task?
faq.answer: If there's even a 1% chance, invoke the skill. The cost of checking is minimal compared to missing better approaches.

faq.question: How do I handle multiple skills that seem relevant?
faq.answer: Follow the priority order: process skills first, then implementation skills. Process skills determine HOW to approach the task.

faq.question: Can I adapt rigid skills to my specific situation?
faq.answer: No. Rigid skills like TDD and debugging must be followed exactly. They contain discipline that produces consistent results.

faq.question: What if I've used this skill before and remember it?
faq.answer: Skills evolve. Always invoke the current version to ensure you have the latest guidance and any updates.

faq.question: How does this skill work in environments without the Skill tool?
faq.answer: Check your platform's documentation for skill loading methods. The protocol remains the same regardless of implementation.
